ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I had almost no knowledge of philosophy of science when I began this class, and I came away from it feeling like I had a great sense of the field as a whole and a thorough understanding of certain key topics and debates.

We learned about core ideas and questions in the philosophy of science, such as Popperian falsification as well as Kuhn's theory of scientific revolutions. I think this course improved how i think about science in general, answering questions such as what makes it a trusted form of knowledge acquisition and what separates science from non-science.

A broad understanding of the philosophy of science as well as a detailed understanding of a handful of important perspectives across history. This course changed how I think as a scientist and how I approach the broader world.
With this being my first philosophy course, not only did I gain knowledge of how science functions as a practice, but also what it means to even think philosophically.

I learned about how philosophy of science has changed and how views on what science should be has evolved over time. The class gave me a new perspective on the role science plays in our society and redefined how I think about scientific objectivtiy.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The readings were extremely informative and useful in understanding the course material, and the in-class discussions were structured well to engage us with the material.
Hard to improve grade in the class if you dont do well on the midterm. The final is a take-home but its very long, and it took me the entire 48 hours to finish

The biggest strength of this course is definitely the thoughtful discussions that Professor Hu would facilitate; i think i learned a lot from the perspectives of my peers.  Also, I think the reading list was excellent.
This class was consistently something I looked forward to attending. Great readings, great discussion, (easy A if you care about that sort of thing), definitely very stimulating.
I thought the structure of class and discussion was excellent.

Strengths: content was engaging, weekly reading was very manageable and overall the course is designed well to offer a good overview of philosophy of science
Weakness: take-home final was very long

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely! Lily is an amazing professor and the content was very interesting!
No, unless youre taking it because you need a philosophy class.

Definitely! For those who are interested in both philosophy and science, this course is a great exploration of their intersection. Specifically I would really encourage anyone to take a class with Professor Hu, as she is incredibly engaging and an excellent lecturer.

Yes in a heartbeat. This class pushed me to think about the world and science in a way that not many other classes have. Dr. Hu is an excellent professor and you will leave this course with a much better understanding of philosophy of science, the world, and perhaps even yourself.
Yes, this course is extremely collaborative and mind opening, especially if you have no experience with philosophy
Yes! I think this course is great for anyone interested in philosophy or science. It does not require any background in philosophy and covers a lot of interesting content and insightful perspectives
